##Why did I write coronaviruses, Bi Shumin told Xinmin Evening News in an exclusive interview?

Micro-signal Yeguangbeifukan

Function introduction the supplement of Xinmin Evening News, founded on May 1,1946, is the oldest comprehensive supplement of Chinese newspapers.

"coronaviruses" was published eight years ago, and in many cases, in real life, it's a reenactment. Some have called the book "Divine Prophecy, " but writer Bi Shumin does not see her work that way. "That was not my intention, " she said in an exclusive interview with the newspaper

Novel

In 2003, she was in Beijing to fight SARS front-line interview.

After eight years of reading, studying, and even dreaming about the virus in its bright, beautiful form, she finally produced a novel. On the back cover of the novel, it reads, "in 200nn, an extremely rare blood-thirsty virus -- the flower cap -- swooped down on Tsubame, a metropolis of tens of millions of people, becoming prey. "

Eight years later, many of the scenes in the book are reproduced in real life. The first 400,000 copies of "coronaviruses" were quickly sold out. Some netizens called the novel "Divine Prophecy, " but author Bi Shumin told the newspaper in an exclusive interview: "That wasn't really my intention. "

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
Bi Shumin's message to Xinmin Evening News readers

Bi Shumin

01
The Sky is falling, the imagination is coming true

01

The Sky is falling, the imagination is coming true

Bi Shumin did not know about the new coronavirus before the general public. "I first saw it on TV and immediately called my friends in Wuhan to ask how things were going? They don't seem to have any special feelings and answer everything as usual. But I lived through SARS, and I knew that this pneumonia of unknown cause, could very well be a disaster, "I didn't hear anything for a couple of days, " she said, noting the news coverage. "Did it suddenly get better? Did it just disappear? Or was there a human element lurking in the air? It was inexplicable and unsettling. " Bi Shumin said, shaken, when she heard Professor Zhong Nanshan Declare "human to human" , "suddenly, the whole world fell apart. "

Bi Shumin was a military doctor in the 1970s

It all fell apart because she knew the virus, she knew the city, she knew human nature. "In my interview with SARS, I got more information than the average person when I was involved in all aspects. The writing of "coronaviruses" was not urgent, but about seven or eight years after the end of SARS. I was able to have more time to gather information and reflect, she came to the conclusion that "humans and viruses will have a war, and even many bloody wars" . As for what happened after the outbreak, Bi Shumin said dryly, "it's all conceivable. "

For example, it is conceivable that there is a shortage of materials, "In any time of disaster, the instinct for self-preservation in a populous country is to hoard the necessities of life. The city is too well-stocked to survive a run on survival, " she says, adding, "I am concerned that a plague in a mega-city would make the problem extremely complex and frightening. "So she chose a big city with a population of ten million or more.

02
Once smelled of SARS

02

Once smelled of SARS

The sense of dread had never been far from Bi Shumin all these years. In the 2003 interview with SARS, from May to July, You'an Hospital, Beijing Chao-yang Hospital, Xiaotangshan Hospital, Beijing Center for Disease Control and Prevention, basic epidemic prevention stations, PLA Academy of Military Medical Sciences, and so on, where more severe cases are treated. "At my suggestion, I went to the Foreign Ministry and the National Meteorological Centre, the Medical Waste Disposal Centre... "

In 2003, Bi Shumin was on an SARS mission

"being so close to the SARS virus, I thought I smelled it, " Bi Shumin said after a pause, "viruses don't have a smell. I may smell a mixture of excrement and disinfectant. But the bag is tightly sealed and the smell is undetectable. I'm just hallucinating with fear. "

The most memorable part of the interview was moving. "The doctors and nurses, if I see them in private, I don't know them. I've never seen their faces, but I remember their voices, I remember them standing up in times of crisis, " Bi Shumin said, at that time, SARS virus habits unknown, in order to prevent the spread of the virus faecal-oral, the patient's excreta can not be directly discharged into the Flush toilet, must be discharged in the Bedpan, and then sprinkled with disinfectant powder, a nurse with a stirring stick manual mixing disinfection. "You can imagine the sordidness and danger of the job. A nurse does this for days on end, until she becomes infected and becomes a patient. I asked the nurse, can't you mechanize? The nurse said, 'where's the time to build a machine? ' When the epidemic is over, people forget, " Bi Shumin said, it's a detail she remembers very well.

03
To fight together, one must have faith

03

To fight together, one must have faith

Wuhan's fight against the epidemic has been a common battle of 1.4 billion Chinese people.

As small as the average person. Bi Shumin had a quiet and simple spring festival. "I didn't even finish watching the gala and went to sleep. Because a good and complete sleep is very important to the body's resistance. " On the first day of the Lunar New Year, I ate frozen dumplings, if you need to go out to buy vegetables, you should reduce or eliminate them as much as possible, "One is that my husband and I are both in our late 20s, and if we can't protect ourselves, we are causing trouble for our children and others. The other is that we are almost out of masks. Now we use them after spraying alcohol on old masks to dry them. The isolation effect is not necessarily perfect. "

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
As big as the country. Bi Shumin, who is in Beijing, is concerned about the outbreak. "I will weep for the heroic sacrifice of the medical staff. I will also worry about the increasing number of patients day by day. I will look forward to the emergence of an antidote and an inflection point even more eagerly. "

This writer with a license to be a psychiatrist, in the preface to "coronaviruses" it is written: "In the event of a mutation in the body and mind, as in the case of extreme adversity in this book, it must ultimately be your mental energy that can be relied upon. " Eight years on, she still believes that mental energy is important, "There is no cure, the only hope is that our minds will not be destroyed, and then mobilize all the power of our body to fight the disease. The other day I heard on the front lines that confidence is more important than medicine. I couldn't agree more. Do not give up the faith in epidemic prevention, once infected, but also do not give up, do not lose heart, mobilize the greatest resistance to recover."

04
If you do not repent, disaster will not be far away

04

If you do not repent, disaster will not be far away

Looking ahead, Bi Shumin said she was confident that the Chinese people would eventually overcome the epidemic. She added: "The lesson is hard to learn, right? I have a prudent faith in the conscience of mankind. There is no repentance. Disaster will surely be waiting for us not far away. There is no chance of that. " She continued to worry, "The reason for writing the coronaviruses was the fear of another plague. Last time it was clear that wild animals were the hosts of the virus, but people got over it and went back to eating wild animals, even as if it were an honor and a Dynamite. What foolish and dangerous thoughts and actions. A man who falls in the same place twice wonders why he doesn't learn. We can not fall a third time."

Bi Shumin with his parents in 1989

On the back cover of the novel, Bi Shumin Asks, "where will fate take us as the human race continues its bloody battle with the virus? " Bi Shumin asks himself. The virus, he says, is far older than man. "If you have to say who is the master of the Earth, the virus is more qualified than we are. The virus is rampant. What kind of mutation did it have? Why run away from the original state, the frenzied invasion of human harm? How can we live in peace with nature's creatures on this Blue Planet? All these are worth us to ponder deeply. Otherwise, when disaster strikes, we don't know where it came from. When the disaster left, we had no idea what had happened to it,"said Xinmin, a reporter for the evening news, bi Shumin wanted to say that it was as if she feared all life, and that she would treat all life on earth with kindness.

_
Interview notes
If there is a call, there is a duty
Seventeen years ago, Bi Shumin was joined by seven others, all reportage writers. Everyone else had written an invitation to go, but she hadn't. Because Bi Shumin was living with his mother, the old man had advanced liver cancer and his life was measured in months and weeks, bi Shumin was afraid that if her mother were to die... "I would probably be quarantined for months. If I could not send her to her death, she would regret it, and I would never forgive myself. So when the collaborators consulted me on this, I said, let me think about it. My mother was there when she heard the call, and she got the gist. And he said unto me, when Thy Kingdom is in trouble, Wilt Thou not go. I said, I'm worried about you. She touched my head and said, child, I promise you, you go about your business. I lived to see you return... and I set out the next day."
Bi Shumin's mother holds her daughter's trophy

Even 17 years later, even though I had to travel from Shanghai to Beijing to cover the epidemic, I still feel the burning sincerity of a writer, in particular, she added: "I am confident that the Chinese people will overcome the epidemic this time. Once the epidemic has subsided, I will assume the mission if called upon. "
I think it is precisely because there are so many doctors and nurses, construction workers and grass-roots cadres like Bi Shumin, ordinary and respectable ordinary workers, kind-hearted compatriots and self-disciplined ordinary people, so that the epidemic can be contained and defeated in the future. I also think, they and we, in the more distant future, no longer be "conscripted" opportunity, no longer need a doctor to shave his head, workers have to stay up all night, no longer need to hug goodbye with tears in their eyes, give up the little ones for everyone. I also think, every small family is good, everyone is good.
_

_
Interview notes

_

Interview notes

If there is a call, there is a duty

Seventeen years ago, Bi Shumin was joined by seven others, all reportage writers. Everyone else had written an invitation to go, but she hadn't. Because Bi Shumin was living with his mother, the old man had advanced liver cancer and his life was measured in months and weeks, bi Shumin was afraid that if her mother were to die... "I would probably be quarantined for months. If I could not send her to her death, she would regret it, and I would never forgive myself. So when the collaborators consulted me on this, I said, let me think about it. My mother was there when she heard the call, and she got the gist. And he said unto me, when Thy Kingdom is in trouble, Wilt Thou not go. I said, I'm worried about you. She touched my head and said, child, I promise you, you go about your business. I lived to see you return... and I set out the next day."
Bi Shumin's mother holds her daughter's trophy

Even 17 years later, even though I had to travel from Shanghai to Beijing to cover the epidemic, I still feel the burning sincerity of a writer, in particular, she added: "I am confident that the Chinese people will overcome the epidemic this time. Once the epidemic has subsided, I will assume the mission if called upon. "
I think it is precisely because there are so many doctors and nurses, construction workers and grass-roots cadres like Bi Shumin, ordinary and respectable ordinary workers, kind-hearted compatriots and self-disciplined ordinary people, so that the epidemic can be contained and defeated in the future. I also think, they and we, in the more distant future, no longer be "conscripted" opportunity, no longer need a doctor to shave his head, workers have to stay up all night, no longer need to hug goodbye with tears in their eyes, give up the little ones for everyone. I also think, every small family is good, everyone is good.
_

Seventeen years ago, Bi Shumin was joined by seven others, all reportage writers. Everyone else had written an invitation to go, but she hadn't. Because Bi Shumin was living with his mother, the old man had advanced liver cancer and his life was measured in months and weeks, bi Shumin was afraid that if her mother were to die... "I would probably be quarantined for months. If I could not send her to her death, she would regret it, and I would never forgive myself. So when the collaborators consulted me on this, I said, let me think about it. My mother was there when she heard the call, and she got the gist. And he said unto me, when Thy Kingdom is in trouble, Wilt Thou not go. I said, I'm worried about you. She touched my head and said, child, I promise you, you go about your business. I lived to see you return... and I set out the next day."
Bi Shumin's mother holds her daughter's trophy

Even 17 years later, even though I had to travel from Shanghai to Beijing to cover the epidemic, I still feel the burning sincerity of a writer, in particular, she added: "I am confident that the Chinese people will overcome the epidemic this time. Once the epidemic has subsided, I will assume the mission if called upon. "
I think it is precisely because there are so many doctors and nurses, construction workers and grass-roots cadres like Bi Shumin, ordinary and respectable ordinary workers, kind-hearted compatriots and self-disciplined ordinary people, so that the epidemic can be contained and defeated in the future. I also think, they and we, in the more distant future, no longer be "conscripted" opportunity, no longer need a doctor to shave his head, workers have to stay up all night, no longer need to hug goodbye with tears in their eyes, give up the little ones for everyone. I also think, every small family is good, everyone is good.

Seventeen years ago, Bi Shumin was joined by seven others, all reportage writers. Everyone else had written an invitation to go, but she hadn't. Because Bi Shumin was living with his mother, the old man had advanced liver cancer and his life was measured in months and weeks, bi Shumin was afraid that if her mother were to die... "I would probably be quarantined for months. If I could not send her to her death, she would regret it, and I would never forgive myself. So when the collaborators consulted me on this, I said, let me think about it. My mother was there when she heard the call, and she got the gist. And he said unto me, when Thy Kingdom is in trouble, Wilt Thou not go. I said, I'm worried about you. She touched my head and said, child, I promise you, you go about your business. I lived to see you return... and I set out the next day."

Bi Shumin's mother holds her daughter's trophy

Even 17 years later, even though I had to travel from Shanghai to Beijing to cover the epidemic, I still feel the burning sincerity of a writer, in particular, she added: "I am confident that the Chinese people will overcome the epidemic this time. Once the epidemic has subsided, I will assume the mission if called upon. "

I think it is precisely because there are so many doctors and nurses, construction workers and grass-roots cadres like Bi Shumin, ordinary and respectable ordinary workers, kind-hearted compatriots and self-disciplined ordinary people, so that the epidemic can be contained and defeated in the future. I also think, they and we, in the more distant future, no longer be "conscripted" opportunity, no longer need a doctor to shave his head, workers have to stay up all night, no longer need to hug goodbye with tears in their eyes, give up the little ones for everyone. I also think, every small family is good, everyone is good.
